It made no reference to the navigation error cited by Carter last week.
According to the account released by CENTCOM on Monday, one of the boats’ diesel engines began to have trouble while it traveled from Kuwait to Bahrain.
The sailors were traveling in small armed vessels known as riverine command boats, headed from Kuwait to Bahrain, which is the location of the Navy’s 5th Fleet.
The sailors were detained Jan. 12 off Farsi Island as they were traveling in two riverine command boats from Kuwait to Bahrain, U S military officials said.
About 19 minutes later, the naval headquarters ”was advised of degraded communications with” the two boats, the account added.
After an additional 26 minutes, the naval headquarters was notified of a total loss of communications with the boats.

By 2:29 p. m. it became hard to reach the U S boats, and by 2:45 U S Naval Central Command (NAVCENT) was notified that the U S military had completely lost communications with the sailors, according to a timeline of events released Monday.
Armed Iranian military personnel boarded the two American vessels while other Iranians kept watch behind machine guns mounted on their vessels.
Armed Iranian military personnel then boarded the U S boats while other Iranian personnel aboard other armed vessels monitored the situation.
First to arrive were two small Iranian craft with armed personnel aboard.

Some hours later, about four hours after the U S first heard that the sailors were being questioned by Iranians, the U S Navy cruiser USS Anzio received word from the Iranians that the sailors were in Iranian custody.
The timeline released Monday said the U S sailors were not mistreated during approximately 15 hours in Iranian hands.
After about 15 hours of detention, the sailors were released.

“Immediately, NAVCENT initiated an intensive search and rescue operation using both air and naval assets including aircraft from USS Harry S Truman and the U S Air Force, and U S Coast Guard, U K Royal Navy and U S Navy surface vessels,” according to the statement released Monday.
Navy command launched    operations soon after, deploying aircraft from USS Harry S Truman and nearby Navy vessels.

CENTCOM says there are no indications that the sailors were physically harmed by Iran and an inventory of the boats found that no weapons were missing but two SIM cards ”appear to have been removed from two handheld satellite phones”.
The only equipment apparently taken from the boats are two digital SIM cards that were in two satellite phones, U S military officials said.
“This stop occurred in Iranian territorial waters, although it’s not clear the crew was aware of their exact location,” the statement said.

The U S military has released its first official account of Iran’s capture and release of 10 American sailors whose vessels entered Iranian waters in the Persian Gulf last week.

In its first official account of Iran’s seizure and subsequent release of 10 U S sailors in the Persian Gulf, the U S military said Monday the only items found missing from their two recovered boats were SIM cards for two satellite phones.

The U S military released new details on Monday about how 10 Navy sailors were taken captive briefly by the Iranian Revolutionary Guards in the Persian Gulf last week, but it remains unclear how the sailors first ended up in Iranian territorial waters before their capture.

WASHINGTON (AP)  —   In its first official account of Iran’s seizure and subsequent release of 10 U S sailors in the Persian Gulf, the U S military said Monday the only items found missing from their two recovered boats were SIM cards for two satellite phones.

The boats were expected to receive additional fuel alongside the Coast Guard cutter Monomoy in international waters around 2 p. m. At about a 2:10 p. m. Navy officials received a report that the sailors were being approached by the Iranians.
The timeline said that approximately 10 minutes after the scheduled refueling, Central Command’s naval headquarters at Bahrain received a report that the boats were being questioned by Iranians.
